The length l_A(M) of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers l such that there is a chain of submodules 0 subsetneq M_1 subsetneq M_2 subsetneq ... subsetneq M_l = M of length l.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
Does the concept of a/an Length of an A-module need to be defined for a definition of a/an Free system of generators (basis) to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a free system of generators (basis) for an A-module M is defined purely in terms of linear independence of a set of elements within the module. This definition involves checking if a linear combination of these elements equals zero, then all the coefficients must be zero. This definition is self-contained and does not rely on any external concepts such as the length of the module.

On the other hand, the length of an A-module is a measure of the complexity of its submodule structure, defined as the supremum of lengths of chains of submodules. This concept is related to the structure and hierarchy of submodules within the module but does not directly influence or necessitate the definition of a basis.

Therefore, the concept of the length of an A-module is not required to define or understand a free system of generators (basis) of an A-module. The two concepts operate independently in the context of module theory, where one deals with linear independence and generating sets, and the other with submodule chains and their lengths.
